column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=FOR PITY’S SAKE
#Text=The library at Tredowen was a room of irregular shape , full of angles and recesses lined with bookcases .
#Text=It was in one of these , standing motionless before a small marble statue of some forgotten Greek poet , that Wingrave found his visitor .

#Text=She wore a plain serge traveling dress , and the pallor of her face , from which she had just lifted a voluminous veil , matched almost in color the gleaming white marble upon which she was gazing .
#Text=But when she saw Wingrave , leaning upon his stick , and regarding her with stern surprise , strange lights seemed to flash in her eyes .
#Text=There was no longer any resemblance between the pallor of her cheeks and the pallor of the statue .
#Text=“ Lady Ruth , ” Wingrave said quietly , “ I do not understand what has procured for me the pleasure of this unexpected visit . ”
#Text=She swayed a little towards him .

#Text=Her head was thrown back , all the silent passion of the inexpressible , the hidden secondary forces of nature , was blazing out of her eyes , pleading with him in the broken music of her tone .
#Text=“ You do not understand , ” she repeated .
#Text=“ Ah , no !
#Text=But can I make you understand ?
#Text=Will you listen to me for once as a human being ?
#Text=Will you remember that you are a man , and I a woman pleading for a little mercy -- a little kindness ? ”
#Text=Wingrave moved a step further back .
#Text=“ Permit me , ” he said , “ to offer you a chair . ”
#Text=She sank into it -- speechless for a moment .
#Text=Wingrave stood over her , leaning slightly against the corner of the bookcase .
#Text=“ I trust , ” he said , “ that you will explain what all this means .
#Text=If it is my help which you require -- ”
#Text=Her hands flashed out towards him -- a gesture almost of horror .
#Text=“ Do n’t , ” she begged , “ you know that it is not that !
#Text=You know very well that it is not .
#Text=Why do you torture me ? ”
#Text=“ I can only ask you , ” he said , “ to explain . ”
#Text=She commenced talking quickly .
#Text=Her sentences came in little gasps .
#Text=“ You wanted revenge -- not in the ordinary way .
#Text=You had brooded over it too long .
#Text=You understood too well .
#Text=Once it was I who sought to revenge myself on you because you would not listen to me !
#Text=You hurt my pride .
#Text=Everything that was evil in me rebelled -- ”
#Text=“ Is this necessary ? ” he interrupted coldly .
#Text=“ I have never reproached you .
#Text=You chose the path of safety for yourself .
#Text=Many another woman in your place would doubtless have done the same thing !
#Text=What I desire to know is why you are here in Cornwall .
#Text=What has happened to make this journey seem necessary to you ? ”
#Text=“ Listen ! ” she continued .
#Text=“ I want you to know how thoroughly you have succeeded .
#Text=Before you came , Lumley and I were living together decently enough , and , as hundreds of others live , with outside interests for our chief distraction .
#Text=You came , a friend !
#Text=You were very subtle , very skillful !
#Text=You never spoke a word of affection to me , but you managed things so that -- people talked .
#Text=You encouraged Lumley to speculate -- not in actual words , perhaps , but by suggestion .
#Text=Then you lent me money .
#Text=Lumley , my husband , let me borrow from you .
#Text=Everyone knew that we were ruined ; everyone knew where the money came from that set us right .
#Text=So misery has been piled upon misery .
#Text=Lumley has lost his self respect , he is losing his ambition , he is deteriorating every day .
#Text=I -- how can I do anything else but despise him ?
#Text=He let me , his wife , come to your rooms to borrow money from you .
#Text=Do you think I can ever forget that ?
#Text=Do you think that he can ?
#Text=Do n’t you know that the memory of it is dragging us apart , must keep us apart always -- always ? ”
#Text=Wingrave leaned a little forward .
#Text=His hands were clasped upon the handle of his stick .
#Text=“ All that you tell me , ” he remarked coldly , “ might equally well have been said in London !
#Text=I do not wish to seem inhospitable , but I am still waiting to know why you have taken an eight hours ’ journey to recite a few fairly obvious truths .
#Text=Your relations with your husband , frankly , do not interest me .
#Text=The deductions which society may have drawn concerning our friendship need scarcely trouble you , under the circumstances . ”
#Text=Then again the light was blazing in her eyes .
#Text=“ Under the circumstances ! ” she repeated .
#Text=“ I know what you mean .
#Text=It is true that you have asked for nothing .
#Text=It is true that all this time you have never spoken a single word which all the world might not hear , you have never even touched my fingers , except as a matter of formality .
#Text=Once I was the woman you loved -- and I -- well you know !
#Text=Is this part of your scheme of torture , to play with me as though we were marionettes , you and I , with sawdust in our veins , dull , lifeless puppets !
#Text=Well , it is finished -- your vengeance !
#Text=You may reap the harvest when you will !
#Text=Publish my letters , prove yourself an injured man .
#Text=Take a whip in your hand if you like , and I will never flinch .
#Text=But , for heaven ’s sake , remember that I am a woman !
#Text=I am willing to be your slave , nurse you , wait upon you , follow you about !
#Text=What more can your vengeance need ?
#Text=You have made me despise my husband , you have made me hate my life with him !
#Text=You have forced me into a remembrance of what I have never really forgotten -- and oh !
#Text=Wingrave , ” she added , opening her arms to him with a little sob , “ if you send me away , I think that I shall kill myself .
#Text=Wingrave ! ”
